{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3230972,"name":"Nadav","username":"Gold87","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gold87/{size}/191382_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-10T19:53:05.390Z","cooked":"

I, Nadav, the Head Programmer of Team 353, am proud to introduce our latest creation, Elastic: A simple and modern Shuffleboard alternative written in Flutter. Elastic has a very similar layout and style to Shuffleboard, but with a more customizable and modern design that is easy to look at in a high pressure environment.

Example Design1920√ó1080 378 KB

Customizability
Elastic is designed to be as customizable as possible to suit any team‚Äôs needs. Some settings include:

  • Color scheme
  • Grid size
  • Update rate of individual widgets
  • Robot size in the Field widget

Just like in Shuffleboard, every widget can be dragged and resized depending on what your team desires.

Better Bandwidth
Elastic has improved on some issues found in other non-hardcoded dashboards. Elastic will only subscribe to the Network Tables topics necessary for displaying the information you want to display, which will save a lot of bandwidth and networking resources.

In addition, if there are 2 widgets that receive data from the same topic, the subscription will be shared between those widgets to further save bandwidth. Once the subscription is no longer being used by anything, the client will unsubscribe to conserve networking resources.

Compatibility with Shuffleboard API
Elastic has backwards compatibility with nearly all of WPILib‚Äôs Shuffleboard API, making it easier to migrate existing layouts to this dashboard. This only applies to code layouts made on a robot program, and not json files that Shuffleboard creates. The only parts of the API that are not compatible with Elastic are:

  • List, Subsystem, & Grid Layouts (These are still being worked on)
  • The buildInto() method
  • Anything related to recording

Downloads, Source Code, and Contributions
In the spirit of Gracious Professionalism, I have decided to make this entire dashboard open source for anybody to use and modify. It is available to download on Windows, MacOS, and Linux. You can find the source code and releases on the Github page linked below.

If you find a bug, have a feature request, or general feedback, feel free to share it! If you want to make your own contributions, you are free to create a pull request on Github. I have had a lot of fun and learned a ton while making this, and I am extremely happy about how it all turned out!

Github Link: GitHub - Gold872/elastic-dashboard: A simple and modern dashboard for FRC teams.

I plan on adding more custom widgets that aren‚Äôt in Shuffleboard (such as AdvantageKit alerts and a swerve drive visualization). In terms of performance, I‚Äôve noticed Elastic uses significantly less memory and processing power. I created the same layout on both dashboards, and Shuffleboard used about 600-800 mb of memory (it fluctuated periodically), and Elastic used about 250-300 mb. In terms of CPU usage, Elastic was about 10-20% lower than what Shuffleboard was using.

Gold87:

such as AdvantageKit alerts and a swerve drive visualization

Just a couple of clarifications because this is often a point of confusion:

  • 6328‚Äôs Shuffleboard plugin for NetworkAlerts is totally unrelated to AdvantageKit. AdvantageKit is a logging and replay library. NetworkAlerts is for displaying persistent alerts, and doesn‚Äôt even have logging integration with AdvantageKit. NetworkAlerts was developed long before AdvantageKit existed.
  • I‚Äôm not sure if you were referring to ‚ÄúAdvantageKit swerve drive visualization‚Äù or not, but just in case I‚Äôll clarify that the AdvantageScope swerve visualizer is also unrelated to AdvantageKit. AdvantageScope is a generic data visualization application for any WPILib project. You can log modules states as a double[] using NT or WPILib‚Äôs DataLogManager and view it using AdvantageScope (soon you‚Äôll even be able to directly log the SwerveModuleState array).

AdvantageKit is a large logging library that requires very significant robot code updates to function, which many teams can‚Äôt or don‚Äôt want to implement. We don‚Äôt want anyone to get the false impression that AdvantageKit is required to use AdvantageScope or NetworkAlerts ‚Äî it absolutely is not.

Very nice work on the tool BTW. I‚Äôm excited to follow your progress as you continue developing it.

I didn‚Äôt realize that NetworkAlerts was separate from AdvantageKit. I saw it in some of the examples linked on the repository so I thought that it was part of it. Is NetworkAlerts still used at all? If it is then I‚Äôll still add a widget to view the alerts in case if a team wants to use it.

With the swerve visualizer, I wasn‚Äôt referring to the one in AdvantageScope, although based on the way I said it it‚Äôs very easy to get that mixed up. The swerve drive visualizer will be completely separate from advantage scope.

Thank you for the clarification!

Gold87:

Is NetworkAlerts still used at all?

Yes, we have used it every year since 2021. The AdvantageKit README links to versions of our competition robot code that contain the Alerts class, but that class is not related to AdvantageKit at all. AdvantageKit doesn‚Äôt include any features for displaying persistent alerts.

Josh Vinod:

Are you able to run two instances of Elastic at once? I know you can‚Äôt do it with Shuffleboard as it insists on crashing.

That was an intentional design decision of Shuffleboard so users didn‚Äôt accidentally end up with multiple copies running, and it also saves the layout into a single global location, so two instances would overwrite each other‚Äôs settings. I‚Äôm curious why you want to run multiple instances at once? Multiple screens?

Warning: Programmer Rant

You might not even need a library, afaik all you‚Äôd need is a file (either stored in a temp directory or the app directory) and write a ‚Äúlock file‚Äù of sorts, indicating that the application is already open.

To communicate to the singleton, attempting to open the project would write to the lock file a command, i.e openNewWindow, and close. The singleton can periodically read from the lock file, and if it detects new commands, follows them and then removes the command from the file. This would essentially be a dumbed-down IPC protocol. Can a ‚Äúmalicious‚Äù application spam commands to eat up resources? Sure, but you can cap the amount of windows to something like 5. Or maybe you can utilize the Shuffleboard API somehow, I dunno.

This would also require changes to the config file to have multiple windows with individual layouts and whatnot.
